result.execSummary:
The defendant Jason M. Fenton was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Methamphetamine, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(g).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Polk County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes:
Must follow all rules of Probation.
Concurrent with: 14CF224/15CF472

miscConds.notes: $290.60 fine/costs to be paid to Probation while on Probation. If not paid by end of Probation, may be reduced to a civil judgment as long as good faith effort has been made.
May not possess or use firearms or body armor.

No contact with David Madison unless permission by Probation. No illegal substances. No elective office. No voting until civil rights restored. If not a U.S. Citizen may face deportation or loss of other civil rights until restored.
Must provide a DNA sample, no surcharge.
Must complete an AODA assessment and compliance.

timeConds.notes:
Subject to work release. NOT subject to good time. 176 days credit if revoked in cases (14CF224/15CF472/16CF14)
Concurrent with: 14CF224/15CF472

superMiscConds.notes: May not possess or use firearms and, if considered a violent felony, no body armor.

Absolute Sobriety.
No illegal drugs.
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.  If not a U.S. Citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.

Any outstanding financial obligations are to be paid through the Department of Corrections while on supervision.  Defendant to pay $50.00 per month if employed once released.  Failure to pay may result in warrant, tax intercept, license suspension and/or civil judgment.
Must complete an AODA assessment and comply with recommendations.
